explanation:
Correct calculation: \( 2\, \text{km}^2 = 2 \times (1000\, \text{m})^2 = 2 \times 1,\!000,\!000\, \text{m}^2 = 2,\!000,\!000\, \text{m}^2 \).

Student's error: \( 2\, \text{km}^2 = 2 \times 10,\!000\, \text{m}^2 = 20,\!000\, \text{m}^2 \).

Flawed reasoning: The student treated \( 1\, \text{km}^2 = 10,\!000\, \text{m}^2 \), implying they replaced the correct squared conversion factor (\( 1000^2 \)) with \( 100 \times 100 \). This occurred because they applied a linear conversion of \( 1\, \text{km} = 100\, \text{m} \) (incorrect) and then squared it, rather than using \( 1\, \text{km} = 1000\, \text{m} \).

Distinction: The error stems from an incorrect linear conversion (using 100 m/km instead of 1000 m/km), not from confusing squaring with doubling or omitting squaring entirely. While related to unit misunderstandings, it specifically involves an erroneous base conversion factor, not misapplying operations like squaring vs. doubling.
